title: How can it be claimed that consciousness creates the universe when consciousness is evidently and conspicuously absent from virtually all of the vast scope of the universe? - Quora

response.answer_text: Simply ignoring for a moment the century of angst and argument that your question has engendered among both physicists and philosophers, by far the simplest answer to your question is that observation is something a lot simpler and enormously more common in the universe than is consciousness. In this perspective, both sentience and consciousness become nothing more than very sparse icing on a very large cake, a cake that is both self-observing and quite able to sustain itself, thank you. In this kind of simple but ubiquitous observation model, massive observation began at least as early as the big bang, and has been very deeply intertwined with matter and existence since. But what would ubiquitous simple observation be, if it is not consciousness? One way to go at that question is to look at experimental physics for what ubiquitous observation is not, that is, what is required to ensure that a system remains quantum. One nicely testable way to describe a quantum system is that it is capable of wave-like behavior, and even more specifically, of self-interference. Self-interference is what makes the two-hole electron experiment so mystifying, since it suggests that an electron in a quantum state can travel through two holes at once. So the question becomes this: What, in the most general terms possible, the is the event that occurs in experiments that destroys quantum states? If this can be identified, it provides an important and possibly critical clue to the nature of simple, consciousness-free observation in physics. Richard Feynman in his Lectures provides provides an excellent clue. In Vol. III Ch 3-4, Identical particles, near start of recorded version (it’s not in printed version!), Feynman say (emphasis his): “... if there is a physical situation in which it is impossible to tell which way it happened, it always interferes; it never fails.” Feynman was emphatic because he found this one-to-one relationship deeply intriguing (and ironically, his Lectures editors did not). As he discusses in the same section, saying that “it is impossible to tell which way it happened” means something far more specific and difficult to achieve than the experimenter simply being ignorant about how the experiment played out. It meant that to remain quantum, there had to be no information anywhere in the universe about the history of the system. Quantum mechanics becomes the physics of systems with undefined histories, systems whose past has not yet been fully determined. The inverse of this situations is that observation occurs when such historical information is created, regardless of where that information is created or whether any conscious entity ever sees it. Observation becomes nothing more than the creation of information. But what is information in that context? In another example Feynman describes how neutrons can reflect wave-like off of a mercury surface mirror. But some fraction of these neutrons are also occasionally captured by mercury nuclei in the surface. When that happens, all wave-like quantum behavior ceases, and the atom itself becomes a human-detectable “record” of how the quantum experiment played out. However, no human is needs to witness the formation of that recording nucleus when the time it occurs, anymore than a human must look at every bit of data collected by a particle collider as it happens. It is enough simply that the atom exists. The mercury nucleus has, in other words, become an observer. It has recorded data on the location of the neutron, and in doing so eliminated all other possible histories that the neutron might have taken. (The more formal term for this is the integral of all possible histories.) But that has to be wrong! After all, the endlessly quoted and discussed Schrödinger’s Cat thought experiment starts with a quantum atom giving off or not giving off a particle, with both options becoming superposed or quantum states. If emitting or absorbing a particle is not quantum, if it is instead a form of historical recording of information, it would mean the entire Schrödinger’s Cat thought experiment is simply incorrect. Surely that cannot be correct! Here’s where another important idea comes into play: Statistical irreversibility versus absolute irreversibility. Information is created not when some event becomes absolutely impossible to reverse, but only pragmatically impossible to reverse. There is a big difference, because it means that almost any kind of weird combination of outcomes can become quantum and uncertain if you work hard enough at it. In that sense, the Schrödinger’s Cat thought experiment expresses a valid point, a point that Schrödinger’s was trying to convey as humorously and facetiously as possible. Folks ever since have taken his bit of humor far more seriously than he ever intended it to be taken. However, the sad truth is that the details of the Schrödinger’s Cat experiment fail to recognize the astronomical statistical irreversibility that occurs as soon as the emitted particle strikes a thermodynamically complex target, the detector. Once that happens, its state becomes part of the astronomically complex and constantly evolving states of thermal matter, and so becomes pragmatically irreversible. Its emission has been observed by the very complexity of the target that it struck, long before it had any effect on the cat. If the same emitted particle had instead somehow been confined to a small region in which there was a very good chance of it being reflected back to the same nucleus that emitted it, with (and this is even harder) a very high probability that it would be reabsorbed by that nucleus, then a real, meaningful superposition of two states (emission and non-emission) would have been possible. This is flatly not what takes place in the Schrödinger’s Cat experiment as it is usually described, and for that reason the emission, far from being quantum, simply becomes a mundane historical event, a non-quantum recording of what transpired to the nucleus. The cat became doomed to real, ordinary, classical death as soon as the emitted particle grew statistically unlikely ever to rejoin the nucleus from which it had been emitted. So what, then, is an observer in a universe that is fully self-observing? The clue again is statistical irreversibility, and one of the best sources of that is matter, especially thermal matter. What is an observer? As with the detector in the real Schrödinger’s Cat experiment, it most often is nothing more complex than an ensemble of atoms whose states are complex enough to make anything that bumps into it statistically unlikely ever to emerge again. Thermal matter is like the sticky mud of the universe, just waiting for naive quantum events to stick their boots in that mud and then, slurp!, lose them forever. Another name this kind of symmetry-destroying, statistically-irreversible, quantum mud boot-stealing is observation. And thus the bottom line is this: The universe doesn’t need us. All it needs is enough complexity to make nominally reversible quantum events sticky and irreversible. For that far simpler goals, grains of dust, molecules, and even atoms can in the right situations record data irreversibly, and thus act as observers. Or, in more personal terms: It’s not your brain that collapses quantum photons from distant stars into points of light, it’s the rhodopsin in your retinas. That may not sound as poetic as ideas like, say, retroactive self-observing Omega Points at the End of the Universe (hmm, maybe next door to the Restaurant?), but it’s an approach to quantum observation that helps spread the workload of maintaining existence a lot more evenly.

How can it be claimed that consciousness creates the universe when consciousness is evidently and conspicuously absent from virtually all of the vast scope of the universe? There is absolutely no evidence, scientific or otherwise that the vast scope of the universe is not contained within consciousness. How we can we say it is “conspicuously absent” when according to the science journal, Nature, we don’t even know what consciousness is and why we have subjective experience? How can we say with any confidence that the universe does not itself have subjective experience? It is natural for man to anthropologize whatever he does not understand. How do we know, for example, that stars and planets do not have a form of consciousness? Just because they do not walk and talk and move about bipedally and parrot humans in every way does not prove they are not conscious. Perhaps they are far more conscious than us. When we take the large expanse of the universe and run a simulation of all the known celestial bodies, including calculations of dark matter and energy, what we get in appearance is not an incoherent distribution of random and chaotic elements in the tradition of mechanistic Darwinian materialism. We get what appears to be an intelligently constructed neural network identical with the neural network of the human brain. To say that such a thing is not the result of an intelligent universe of some type is the hubris of a self-absorbed pseudo-skeptic who lacks any imagination whatsoever.

That is, all matter will die, decay, erode, dissolve and cease to exist. All things not made of matter, have not been successfully discovered by science, so there is no physical evidence to support any claim to them. At the same time, it is a known fact that consciousness exists. It is experienced by every sentient life form. So applying physical law (matter disintegrates according to its finite properties), what is non-matter exists without a timeline. Therefore, what is non-matter must have always existed. We already accept that energy was always here. And now we know consciousness must have always been here. More so, conscious energy was always present and preceded physical creation.

We are accustomed to things that come and go, that are born and die, that begin and end. So when we are faced with the prospect of a universe that has no beginning and ending, we have no comparison to offer. We struggle with the distinction between a universe and an “observable” universe, with the difference between a cosmos (where all things are arranged in an order) and a universe that is just a happening. To add to that the vagueness of “consciousness” just complicates it beyond our comprehension. However, until we have better answers to the history of the universe and the composition of human self-awareness, we can expect confusion.

That’s exactly why. If consciousness arose here as a natural phenomenon through an evolutionary process, we would expect to see it everywhere in the universe through the same process, given that there are an estimated 200 billion galaxies out there. On the other hand, if consciousness arose first and then brought the universe into being, we would not be surprised to see consciousness in one place, surrounded by a colossal universe devoid of other consciousness.
